steps.name: Welcome to Glacier Bay, Alaska
steps.body:
You will need to do the following in order to set up the General NOAA Operational Modeling Environment for Glacier Bay :

  1. Set the model run parameters.
  2. Input the wind conditions.

steps.title: Model Settings
steps.buttons: <button type='button' class='cancel' data-dismiss='modal'>Cancel</button><button type='button' class='back'>Back</button><button type='button' class='next'>Next</button>

steps.title: Wind Type
steps.buttons: <button type='button' class='cancel' data-dismiss='modal'>Cancel</button><button type='button' class='back'>Back</button><button type='button' class='next'>Next</button>
steps.body:
Wind can significantly influence oil movement and can force oil to move in a different direction from the currents.

You can choose wind that is constant in direction and speed for the entire model run, or you can choose wind that varies in direction and/or speed over time.

steps.buttons: <button type='button' class='cancel' data-dismiss='modal'>Cancel</button><button type='button' class='back'>Back</button><button type='button' class='next'>Next</button>

steps.title: Considerations
steps.body:
Glacier Bay is a recently deglaciated fjord that still contains many small active tidewater glaciers.

Glacier Bay exhibits processes which make predicting surface currents and spill trajectories difficult, such as:

  1. Large amounts of freshwater runoff
  2. High sedimentation rates that change local bathymetry
  3. Rapid currents that cause complete water column mixing
  4. Winds channeled by steep orography

steps.title: Almost Done
steps.body:
You are ready to move to the Map Window to start your spill and run the model. Here are the tools you'll use :

To set the location of your spill(s), you will use the Spill Tool.

To run the model, you will use GNOME's run controls: Run, Pause, and Step.
